physDesc.p: Five pages typewritten in black ink. Archival notes read "Aldington" in pencil at the top of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I was delighted to get your letter. In fact, I am sorry to say that I am in debt to you for two since I wrote. I was even more delighted to get yours and Richard’s photographs. They will be the greatest pleasure and comfort to me, and I shall have them where I can see them constantly.

I had already made up my mind to write to Richard all the time, whether I received letters from him or not. I can imagine what it must be like to get news from the outside world, and you need not fear that I shall not keep you informed as to the situation here, to the best of my ability.

I wish I could go over and see you. It has been on my mind to take a steamer and go over for a few weeks, just to show my interest and friendship for you and Richard, before he goes to the front. After considering this, I have decided not to go, for reasons which I hope you will consider conclusive. In the first place, I do not think the sea is very safe at the moment; and although I have a right to risk my own life, I do not think I have a right to risk anyone else’s, and Mrs. Russell absolutely refuses to let me go over without going with me. In the second place, now that Fletcher has gone away, I think it extremely important to stay here and keep all our names before the public. This I am wearing myself to skin and bones to do. And I know that is what Richard would care to have me do, more than to see him personally. As soon as the war is over, I shall go across at once. But just now, you must regard me as staying here to help along the cause.

I have sold two of Richard’s poems to the "Poetry Review" – "Images" and "Inarticulate Grief." The rest of the poems I have sent to Harriet for consideration. She is not as enthusiastic about them as she ought to be, but she has asked to keep them awhile longer before answering.

I have also sold Richard’s essay on Mallarmé to the "Poetry Review." The poems appear in the August issue, as you will see. How soon they will print the essay, I do not know. They are supposed to pay on acceptance, but they do not – they pay on publication, and not very promptly then; so I am afraid I shall not have any money to send Richard for about a month.

I have also sold his article on "Henri de Régnier" to "The Dial." They have agreed to pay $5.00 for it. This is not high, and I fear Braithwaite will not pay more, if as much; but it is quite impossible to get these slight, exquisite things into the regular, stodgy, high-pay magazines. "The Dial" has a very large circulation, and I thought it better to accept it.
I am trying to get the editor of "The Drama" to pay Richard what he owes him, but without a power-of-attorney it is a little difficult; however, I do not yet despair.

His article on "Pierre Louys" I do not think I can sell. Louys’ writing is not the kind of thing that takes the American public, and Braithwaite, the editor of "The Dial," and Harriet have all refused it; and I do not think there is any use in expecting it to be printed in any of the paying magazines. Of course, Margaret Anderson will take it for the "Little Review," if you would like me to send it to her, only of course she does not pay.

"The Dial" printed an attack upon us by a man named H. E. Warner in their Correspondence Column, in which he foolishly and idiotically criticized the part of your poem about the heat blunting the pears. I make a rule of never answering attacks, but I have answered this letter only, however, to repudiate a misquotation he gives from me. I think it always wiser for us not to answer attacks personally, and it seems quite impossible to explain to such an unimaginative man why your poem is beautiful. Also, being one of the group, things of that sort do not have the same effect from us that they do from other people. But I have asked a very good friend of mine, a man of a great deal of scholarship and of interest in our work, who has already written a long and interesting article on the Imagists which he is trying to have published, to answer it; and I hope he will do so.

"The Dial" has changed hands, having been bought by a man named Martyn Johnson who, although not quite so radical as we could wish, is nevertheless thoroughly in sympathy with our work. He has asked me to write critical essays for him and, as you see, he has accepted Richard’s article on Régnier. "The Dial" has hitherto been the most reactionary paper we have. His object is to change it gradually until it becomes sympathetic to the new movements. He must do this slowly, and I think he has begun very well by making Dr. C. J. Masseck the editor. I do not know Dr. Masseck, but everyone tells me that he is in favour of all that we are trying to do. The ball is rolling steadily and constantly, and I do not think we need have any fear for the future.

As I wrote Richard sometime ago, I am to give a series of four lectures on modern American poets this Winter in various cities. The poets I am dealing with are Edwin Arlington Robinson, Robert Frost, Masters, Carl Sandburg, and the Imagists. Of course, as they are American poets, I cannot say as much as I wish I could about Richard and Lawrence and Flint, but I shall run them in in the Imagist lecture, although it will be chiefly about you and Fletcher.

Can you send me a little biographical detail about yourself and about Richard? I should like to have Richard’s for future use, and I want yours for these lectures. I want to know where you were born, and when; where you were educated, and more or less what your life was like; where you travelled; what you thought; what you read; what interested you. I am going to publish these lectures afterwards in a book, and the arrangement will be about like that of my "French Poets" – some biography, a great deal of criticism, and a lot of quotation. In spite of all these poets being alive, I think I can take a leaf out of the French practice, and write about them now. I am giving these lectures in Boston, at the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences in Brooklyn, at the Little Theatre in Chicago, and possibly in St. Louis and Philadelphia; and Macmillan has already agreed to publish them a year from now. All of which is very satisfactory.

Please tell Richard that his going to the war will only be an interlude, and an interlude which I have no doubt will be an interesting experience, that he will not in any way get out of the running here, and that I shall keep his name alive, and do my best to place his things, until he comes back.

Keep your courage up, Dear Girl, and I really do believe this war will soon be over. I think Germany is on her last legs. Richard writes that your courage and self-sacrifice have helped him inconceivably, and that is a glorious thing for you to feel. We believe that poetry is virile, not decadent and weak, and things such as you are going through can only deepen and broaden your poetry, and that is what I know you both live for.
Mrs. Russell send her love, and you know you have mine. I am not writing to Richard by this mail; this is to him as well as to you.
Please find out if Lawrence is in want because, if so, I should like to send you some money to send him, or send it to him direct, as you may think best. He is proud, and one has to go carefully.
body.closer: With a great deal of love,
